summary.p: Dialogues on the Old Testament, that is, on Kings 3, Kings 4, Paralipomenon, Ezra, Tobit, Esther, Judith, Job, and Maccabee.

This is the first of the three volumes of a multi-volume manuscript of dialogues (callāpaṅkaḷ) on the Old Testament, that is,
BnF Indien 450
BnF Indien 451
BnF Indien 452

According to Richard (1989, pp. 161-163), with convincing arguments, this multi-volume manuscript could be the oldest known translation of the Bible into Tamil, made between 1666 and 1677 by the capuchin fathers Ephrem de Nevers (1607/10-1695) and Zénon de Baugé (1603?-1687). More precisely, this is an adaptation, as this is a dialogue between a master and a disciple on the various books of the Bible.
Description based on the examination of the original manuscript (April 2021).
Dimensions assessed at the time of examination.
The images are in the reversed order on Gallica microfilm.

origin.origDate: 1729 at the latest, as described in the list of books sent this year by the Jesuits of Pondicherry. Dated to circa 1750 by Vinson in Vinson et al. (1866-) and to 1750 by Cabaton (1912), on unstated grounds (presumably palaeographical and material analysis arguments). It is not clear if the date 1867 in the final colophon (U3, f312r2-f312r3), presumably in the Christian era, is the date of the manuscript copy, a date copied from an antigraph, if any, or the date of the work.

provenance.p: Acquired or copied in Pondicherry by the Jesuits of Pondicherry.

acquisition.p: This manuscript appears to be the third of three volumes referred to as a single-volume Bible and Bible en Malabar ou Tamoul sent by the Jesuits of the Mission du Carnate in 1729 for the library of the king of France and mentioned in ancien lists (BnF NAF 5442, f5r and f9r). See Cabaton (1912), who dates however this manuscript to 1743. These lists state that this Bible, as well as the next two items in the list are printed by the Lutheran missionnaries from Tranquebar and are from the Danish Protestants.

encodingDesc.p: General ― Unmarked length of ō and ē supplied. Unmarked puḷḷi supplied. Conjectural reading (text unclear) between parentheses. Supplied reading (text lost) between square brackets. Alternative readings separated by slash. In transliteration ― Unmarked elided overshort u supplied as an apostrophe. Uppercase for initial vowels. Symbols between curly brackets. Abbreviations ― c = column; f = folio; lf = library foliation; lm = left margin; r = recto; rm = right margin; u / U followed by a number = unit (codicological and/or textual); v = verso.
